title: Baseline: Cardano UTXO lookup via /api/v2/txs/utxoForAddresses
asset: Exodus desktop wallet - Cardano UTXO backend (cardano.a.exodus.io)
privileged_role: Wallet A - Exodus Cardano account that owns the addresses being queried (test wallet you control)
unprivileged_role: Wallet B - Separate Exodus Cardano account you also control, used only for safe A/B testing
summary: Baseline description for how the Exodus desktop wallet queries Cardano UTXOs for a list of user-controlled addresses via /api/v2/txs/utxoForAddresses. This file is NOT a confirmed vulnerability; it documents expected behavior and provides a structure for future BOLA/IDOR or privacy tests using two wallets you control.
impact: Currently baseline only: demonstrates how Exodus resolves Cardano UTXOs for specific wallet addresses.

If a future test showed that Wallet B can query or obtain private metadata about Wallet A's addresses beyond what is public on-chain, this could become a BOLA/IDOR-style privacy issue (CWE-200 / CWE-639).
steps: Create two Exodus Cardano wallets you control: Wallet A and Wallet B (each with its own seed and addresses).

With Wallet A selected in the Exodus desktop wallet, perform an action that triggers a balance refresh for Cardano (e.g., open the Cardano asset view). Capture the POST /api/v2/txs/utxoForAddresses request in Burp and note the addresses[] values.
Repeat the same with Wallet B and capture its own utxoForAddresses request. Confirm that addresses[] contains only Wallet B's addresses.
Offline, compare the two captured requests and responses and document which fields are wallet-specific (addresses, any metadata) and which are generic.

If you ever discover that a Wallet B session can successfully query Wallet A's addresses in a way that returns non-public metadata or unexpected fields, clone this baseline file into a high-severity Exodus BOLA finding JSON and populate privileged/unprivileged request/response fields for report generation.
